canonical_explanation.text: An angle is formed when two rays share a common starting point (vertex). Angles are measured in degrees. An acute angle is less than 90°. A right angle is exactly 90°. An obtuse angle is between 90° and 180°. A straight angle is exactly 180°. A reflex angle is between 180° and 360°. A protractor is used to measure angles. Complementary angles add up to 90°. Supplementary angles add up to 180°.
rules: Acute angle: greater than 0° and less than 90°
Obtuse angle: greater than 90° and less than 180°
Reflex angle: greater than 180° and less than 360°
Complementary angles: two angles that add up to 90°
Supplementary angles: two angles that add up to 180°
A protractor measures angles from 0° to 180°

questions.question_text: An angle less than 90° is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An angle that measures less than 90° is called an acute angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angles less than 90° are acute. Right = 90°, obtuse = between 90° and 180°, straight = 180°.

questions.question_text: A right angle measures exactly:
questions.explanation_correct: A right angle is exactly 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A right angle = 90°. It is the angle at the corner of a square or rectangle.

questions.question_text: An angle of 120° is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: 120° is between 90° and 180°, so it is an obtuse angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Any angle greater than 90° and less than 180° is obtuse. 120° falls in this range.

questions.question_text: A straight angle measures:
questions.explanation_correct: A straight angle is exactly 180° — it forms a straight line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A straight angle = 180°. The two rays form a straight line.

questions.question_text: An angle of 89° is an acute angle.
questions.explanation_correct: 89° is less than 90°, so it is an acute angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Any angle from 0° to less than 90° is acute. 89° < 90°, so it is acute.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an obtuse angle?
questions.explanation_correct: 145° is between 90° and 180°, making it an obtuse angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Obtuse angles are > 90° and < 180°. Only 145° fits this range.

questions.question_text: The angle at each corner of a square is:
questions.explanation_correct: Each corner of a square has a 90° angle, which is a right angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All four corners of a square are right angles (90° each).

questions.question_text: At 6 o'clock, the hands of a clock form a:
questions.explanation_correct: At 6:00, the hour and minute hands point in opposite directions, forming a straight angle of 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 6 o'clock, the hands form a straight line = 180° = straight angle.

questions.question_text: What type of angle does a clock show at 2 o'clock?
questions.explanation_correct: At 2:00, the angle between the hands is 60° (each hour = 30°, so 2 × 30° = 60°), which is acute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 2 o'clock, the hands form a 60° angle, which is less than 90° (acute).

questions.question_text: An angle of 91° is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: 91° is greater than 90° and less than 180°, so it is an obtuse angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even though 91° is just 1° more than a right angle, it is still classified as obtuse (between 90° and 180°).

questions.question_text: Which instrument is used to measure angles?
questions.explanation_correct: A protractor is the instrument used to measure angles in degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A protractor has markings from 0° to 180° and is used to measure angles.

questions.question_text: A protractor can measure angles from:
questions.explanation_correct: A standard protractor measures angles from 0° to 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A protractor is a semicircular tool that measures from 0° to 180°.

questions.question_text: A protractor has two scales — an inner scale and an outer scale.
questions.explanation_correct: A protractor has two scales reading in opposite directions (0-180 and 180-0) to measure angles from either side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two scales on a protractor allow you to measure angles opening to the left or right.

questions.question_text: To measure an angle, where should the centre of the protractor be placed?

options.text: On one arm of the angle
On the vertex of the angle

questions.explanation_correct: The centre point of the protractor must be placed exactly on the vertex (corner point) of the angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Always place the protractor's centre on the vertex of the angle for accurate measurement.

questions.question_text: Riya measured an angle and got 65°. What type of angle is it?
questions.explanation_correct: 65° is less than 90°, so it is an acute angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 65° < 90°, which means it is an acute angle.

questions.question_text: Arjun measured an angle as 135°. What type of angle is it?
questions.explanation_correct: 135° is between 90° and 180°, so it is an obtuse angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 135° > 90° and < 180°, making it obtuse.

questions.question_text: One arm of an angle is on the 0° mark and the other arm points to the 72° mark on a protractor. The angle is:
questions.explanation_correct: If one arm is at 0° and the other is at 72°, the angle measures 72° − 0° = 72°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Read the difference between the two marks: 72° − 0° = 72°.

questions.question_text: Meena placed the protractor with one arm at 30° and the other at 110°. What is the angle?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Subtract the two readings: 110° − 30° = 80°.

questions.question_text: Two complementary angles add up to:
questions.explanation_correct: Complementary angles are two angles whose sum is 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary = adds to 90°. Supplementary = adds to 180°.

questions.question_text: Two supplementary angles add up to:
questions.explanation_correct: Supplementary angles are two angles whose sum is 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary angles together make a straight angle (180°).

questions.question_text: What is the complement of 30°?
questions.explanation_correct: Complement of 30° = 90° − 30° = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles add to 90°. So complement = 90° − 30° = 60°.

questions.question_text: What is the supplement of 110°?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary angles add to 180°. So supplement = 180° − 110° = 70°.

questions.question_text: The complement of 45° is:
questions.explanation_correct: Complement of 45° = 90° − 45° = 45°. So 45° is its own complement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° − 45° = 45°. Interesting — 45° is its own complement!

questions.question_text: The supplement of 90° is:
questions.explanation_correct: Supplement of 90° = 180° − 90° = 90°. A right angle is its own supplement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 180° − 90° = 90°. Two right angles are supplementary.

questions.question_text: Two acute angles can be complementary.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes! For example, 30° and 60° are both acute and add to 90° (complementary).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles add to 90°, so both must be acute (less than 90°).

questions.question_text: Two obtuse angles can be supplementary.
questions.explanation_correct: Two obtuse angles would each be more than 90°, so their sum would exceed 180°. They cannot be supplementary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each obtuse angle > 90°, so sum > 180°. Supplementary requires sum = 180°.

questions.question_text: If one angle is 55°, what is its complement?
questions.explanation_correct: Complement = 90° − 55° = 35°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles sum to 90°: 90° − 55° = 35°.

questions.question_text: If one angle is 73°, what is its supplement?
questions.explanation_correct: Supplement = 180° − 73° = 107°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary angles add to 180°: 180° − 73° = 107°.

questions.question_text: When you open a book partially, the angle between the covers is likely:
questions.explanation_correct: When a book is only slightly open, the angle between the covers is less than 90° (acute).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A partially opened book forms an acute angle (less than 90° between covers).

questions.question_text: A fully opened door against the wall makes approximately a:
questions.explanation_correct: A door fully opened against the wall forms approximately 180° (a straight angle) with its original position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A fully open door lies flat against the wall = approximately 180° = straight angle.

questions.question_text: Which angle is greater: obtuse or right?
questions.explanation_correct: An obtuse angle (between 90° and 180°) is always greater than a right angle (exactly 90°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Obtuse > 90° > right angle (which is exactly 90°).

questions.question_text: An angle that measures exactly 180° is called a ___ angle.
questions.explanation_correct: A 180° angle forms a straight line, so it is called a straight angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 180° = straight angle (the two arms form a straight line).

questions.question_text: Kavya says the angle is 50° but Priya says it is 130°. They are reading the same angle on a protractor. Who might be reading the wrong scale?

options.text: Either could be wrong — depends on which arm is at the baseline

questions.explanation_correct: A protractor has two scales. The correct reading depends on which scale aligns with the baseline arm. 50° + 130° = 180°, so they are reading opposite scales.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 50° and 130° add to 180° — this means one is reading the inner scale and the other the outer scale. Which is correct depends on the baseline.

questions.question_text: How many right angles make a straight angle?
questions.explanation_correct: A straight angle = 180° = 2 × 90° = 2 right angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 180° ÷ 90° = 2 right angles make one straight angle.

questions.question_text: How many right angles make a complete turn (full angle)?
questions.explanation_correct: A complete turn = 360° = 4 × 90° = 4 right angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 360° ÷ 90° = 4 right angles make a full turn.

questions.question_text: Can a right angle have a complement?

options.text: No, a right angle has no complement

questions.explanation_correct: Complement of 90° = 90° − 90° = 0°. So the complement is a zero angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° − 90° = 0°. A 0° angle (zero angle) is the complement of a right angle.

questions.question_text: The angle formed by the hands of a clock at 3 o'clock is:
questions.explanation_correct: At 3:00, the minute hand is at 12 and hour hand at 3. The angle = 3 × 30° = 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each hour on a clock = 30°. At 3 o'clock, angle = 3 × 30° = 90°.

questions.question_text: What angle does a clock show at 4 o'clock?
questions.explanation_correct: At 4:00, the angle between hands = 4 × 30° = 120° (obtuse).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each hour = 30°, so 4 hours = 4 × 30° = 120°.

questions.question_text: The baseline of a protractor is also called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The flat bottom edge of the protractor is the straight edge or zero line — one arm of the angle is aligned along this line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The baseline is the straight edge at the bottom of the protractor, aligned with 0° and 180°.

questions.question_text: The complement of 60° is ___°
questions.explanation_correct: Complement = 90° − 60° = 30°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles add to 90°: 90° − 60° = 30°.

questions.question_text: The supplement of 45° is ___°
questions.explanation_correct: Supplement = 180° − 45° = 135°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary angles add to 180°: 180° − 45° = 135°.

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT an acute angle?
questions.explanation_correct: 90° is a right angle, not an acute angle. Acute angles are strictly less than 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An acute angle must be less than 90°. 90° is a right angle.

questions.question_text: To draw an angle of 75°, you should use a:
questions.explanation_correct: To draw an angle of any given measure, you need a protractor to mark the angle and a ruler to draw the arms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Use a protractor to measure 75° and a ruler to draw straight arms.

questions.question_text: A reflex angle is greater than 180° but less than 360°.
questions.explanation_correct: A reflex angle measures between 180° and 360°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflex angles: 180° < angle < 360°.

questions.question_text: Two angles are complementary. One is 28°. The other is:
questions.explanation_correct: Complement = 90° − 28° = 62°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles add to 90°: 90° − 28° = 62°.

questions.question_text: Two angles are supplementary. One is 125°. The other is:
questions.explanation_correct: Supplement = 180° − 125° = 55°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary angles add to 180°: 180° − 125° = 55°.

questions.question_text: Arrange these angles in ascending order: 95°, 45°, 180°, 90°
questions.explanation_correct: Ascending order (smallest to largest): 45° < 90° < 95° < 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From smallest to largest: 45°, 90°, 95°, 180°.

questions.question_text: The centre point of a protractor should be placed on the arm of the angle.
questions.explanation_correct: The centre point of a protractor should be placed on the vertex (corner) of the angle, not on its arm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The centre must be at the vertex. One arm aligns with the baseline.

questions.question_text: Can two right angles be supplementary?

options.text: No, because they are both equal

questions.explanation_correct: 90° + 90° = 180°. Since supplementary angles add to 180°, two right angles are supplementary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Supplementary means sum = 180°. Two right angles: 90° + 90° = 180°. Yes, they are supplementary.

questions.question_text: A complete rotation (full turn) equals ___°
questions.explanation_correct: A complete rotation or full turn is 360°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A full turn = 360° = 4 right angles.
